channel.title: NYT > Top Stories

item.title: As Trump Weighs Possible Iran Strikes, U.S. Military Moves Into Place
item.description: President Trump has given no indication that he has made a decision about how to proceed, as diplomatic talks continue.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jonathan Klein/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier, seen here in the North Sea last year, is making its way toward the Middle East.

item.title: Maps: Where the U.S. Is Building Up Military Force Near Iran
item.description: President Trump has not authorized military action in Iran, but the United States has built up its presence in the region in recent weeks. Now it’s sending even more firepower.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl, Eric Schmitt, Ashley Cai, Riley Mellen and Daniel Wood
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Sugar Bowl Academy Says Multiple Victims Were Tied to Its Ski Resort School
item.description: Sugar Bowl Academy, a ski-focused private school in the Sierra Nevada, said that multiple people on the fatal trek were connected to its program.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla, Sabrina Tavernise and Deb Wandell
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trail to Castle Peak near Donner Pass. Eight backcountry skiers are confirmed dead from an avalanche in the Castle Peak area at Donner Pass.

item.title: Satellite Feature on iPhone Allowed Skiers to Seek Help After Avalanche
item.description: The Emergency SOS feature on iPhones can send texts to emergency responders via satellite when there is no cell tower nearby.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang

item.title: What To Know About the Trial of Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea’s Ousted Leader
item.description: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol was sentenced to life imprisonment after being found guilty on Thursday of leading an insurrection with his short-lived imposition of martial law in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk Yeol in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: As ICE Buys Up Warehouses, Even Some Trump Voters Say No
item.description: The agency is ramping up arrests, but local pushback is complicating efforts to expand detention capacity and prevent overcrowding.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo, Hamed Aleaziz and Allison McCann
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stacy Bradley, right, and Sarah Wellman in the parking lot of their cheerleading gym in Surprise, Ariz. The federal government plans to convert the warehouse at right into a detention center for immigrants.

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.description: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane belonging to Donald J. Trump arrived at Palm Beach International Airport in 2023. Florida Republicans have advanced an effort to rename the airport “President Donald J. Trump International Airport.”

item.title: Officials Violated Court Orders on Immigration in New Jersey, Justice Dept. Tells Judge
item.description: The violations stemmed from immigration cases. Judges across the country have expressed alarm about illegal transfers and missed deadlines.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz, Zach Montague and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside Delaney Hall detention center in Newark, N.J., in December.

item.title: These Olympians Excel on Two Types of Tracks
item.description: Among elite athletes exists an even more exclusive club: people who compete at both the Summer and Winter Games. Many are sprinters who turn to bobsled.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Salomé Kora, left, will compete for a Swiss two-woman bobsled team this week in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: Administration Targets Noncitizen Voting, Despite Finding It Rare
item.description: The intensified push is part of an extraordinary all-fronts effort to insert federal law enforcement into the machinery of American elections ahead of the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Devlin Barrett, Alan Feuer, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Miami Beach in 2024. A new nationwide effort by the Trump administration to find and charge criminal voting cases appears to be targeted at green card holders.

item.title: Texas Election Season Heats Up as Early Voting in Senate Primaries Begins
item.description: Both parties’ Senate primary races are kicking into high gear.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times

item.title: Russia Celebrated Him. Now He’s Accused of Having Troops Shoot Themselves.
item.description: A lieutenant colonel is on trial after being accused of skimming payments for battlefield injuries. He denies the specifics of Russia’s accusation but acknowledges engaging in a payouts scheme.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ksenia Churmanova
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recruitment poster in Moscow last year. The military has struggled to root out endemic corruption.

item.title: The Behind the Scenes Search for Compromise on Territory in Ukraine Talks
item.description: The latest round of talks ended with no indication of progress, but negotiators are bargaining over who will control land in eastern Ukraine if they reach a settlement.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers monitor the sky for Russian drones in the Donetsk region of Ukraine in December.

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.description: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The India A.I. Impact Summit unfolded across 120 acres in New Delhi this week, featuring more than 300 exhibitors and 500 sessions. Organizers expected about 250,000 participants and visitors.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.description: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Defense Department and Anthropic have been negotiating a contract over A.I. use by the Pentagon.

item.title: Kansas, Idaho, Utah, Oklahoma in New Push to Restrict Transgender Rights
item.description: In states that once focused mainly on health care and sports for transgender minors, debates now revolve around the validity of transgender identity.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstrator outside the U.S. Supreme Court as the court heard arguments last month concerning transgender athletes participating in girls sports.

item.title: After Activist’s Killing, Tensions Erupt Between France’s Far-Right and Far-Left
item.description: The beating death of Quentin Deranque has quickly become a flashpoint between the far right and far left as France prepares for local elections next month and presidential elections next year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Olivier Chassignole/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An area near the site of the brawl in Lyon, France, that led to the beating death of Quentin Deranque, on Saturday.

item.title: In Guthrie Mystery, Rampant Speculation Is Like ‘Salt on the Open Wound’
item.description: True crime obsessives, internet theorizers and livestreamers are complicating the investigation of the kidnapping of Nancy Guthrie, the mother of the “Today” show host Savannah Guthrie.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: NBC/Today, via Reuters
item.media:description: Family members of Nancy Guthrie, mother of the TV anchor Savannah Guthrie, are “real people with hearts and souls,” a friend said.

item.title: Ethan Hawke on ‘Blue Moon,’ ‘Reality Bites’ and the Lessons He’s Learned
item.description: A best actor Oscar contender for “Blue Moon,” the star reflects on turbulent times in Hollywood and the notion of selling out: “I think about it constantly.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sela Shiloni
item.media:credit: Sela Shiloni for The New York Times
item.media:description: Acting is “such a wonderful profession,” Hawke said, explaining, “You can use your own joys and heartbreaks and relationships to educate you, then put it in service of something else.”

item.title: With a New Oscar on the Line, How Do You Judge Casting?
item.description: Contenders say the criteria for judging the category can vary from, say, the number of newcomers to the seamlessness of the ensemble.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: Kennedy’s MAHA Coalition Is a Mess
item.description: A political movement cannot survive on spite alone.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: One Man Stole $660 Million. He’ll Never Pay It Back.
item.description: Ordinary citizens have a range of legal tools to hold the rich and politically connected accountable.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Ballou

item.title: Stephen Colbert Sizes Up R.F.K. Jr.’s Workout With Kid Rock
item.description: “The Late Show” host called the 90-second video of the two working up a sweat together “pure cinema.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Bernie Sanders Urges Support of California Billionaire Tax at Los Angeles Rally
item.description: The senator from Vermont was the only elected leader at the event, which formally kicked off a health care union’s campaign to put the tax proposal on the ballot.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders, Independent of Vermont, speaks in Los Angeles on Wednesday in support of a proposed California ballot issue that would impose a tax on billionaires in the state.

item.title: Texas Congressman’s Aide Told Co-Worker of Affair Before Killing Herself
item.description: The co-worker, who no longer works for Representative Tony Gonzales, shared screenshots of the text exchange with The New York Times. Mr. Gonzales accused his Republican primary challenger of being behind the revelation.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tony Gonzales in Washington this month.

item.title: Shipwreck Found at the Bottom of Lake Michigan After Nearly 150 Years
item.description: The steamer Lac La Belle, which was carrying passengers and cargo, sank in a storm in 1872. Eight people died when one of its lifeboats capsized.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Ali Watkins

item.title: Police Chief Hired to Help Lead N.Y.C. Hospital Patrols Abruptly Quits
item.description: The assistant chief, Jamiel Altaheri, resigned almost immediately after starting the job, after The New York Times asked about misconduct allegations while he was a police chief in Michigan.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.category: New York City Health and Hospitals Corp
